bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, July 28, 1942

div1.p: Taylor informs Hench that he has additional documents concerning the yellow fever experiments, and that his other information comes from memories of having worked with many of the central figures.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, July 28, 1942
div1.opener:
1)Ask me room in Los A where (sells)
Maas died - same as Lazear
2)ask if friends 3)
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby
Pennsylvania.
July 28, 1942
Dr Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester. Minn.
Dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of July 24 received. Agree with
you, hope to meet you in the near future. Yes, I have
data regarding yellow fever, clippings, records, booklets,
illustrations from original photographs, etc, some I am sure
would be of valuable interest in your proposed article.

When I refer to information I have in mind, I
refer to that obtained from actual working contact
with Guiteras, Finlay, Lebredo, Agramonte, Albertini,
Carroll and many others during my long years of
laboratory service.

When I get your list of questions, will be
able to go into detail, but for the present not
knowing the subjects you propose to cover, will adopt
your good trait of brevity in writing. A question from
me, was it, or is it your intention to include something
referring to Miss Clara, Louise Maass, the Nurse who
died from experimental yellow fever at Las Animas Hospital. A very good plan
to give me later your Army address, as I may pick up
some news for you. Enclosed find clipping; no comment.
